tit.e: Naisenshi (dyeing branch of the Imperial Household Ministry)
tit.cmt: 「内染司」を、Naisenshi (dyeing branch of the Imperial Household Ministry)としました。
他の「司」の訳と統一するため補足修正 (参照: http://www.unterstein.net/or/docs/JapanRanks.pdf)

sen.j: 内染司（ないせんし）は律令制において宮内省に属する機関の一つである。
sen.e: Naisenshi was an institution belonging to Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household) in the Ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code).

sen.j: 内染司は天皇・皇后に供御する糸・布・織物類の染色をつかさどった。
sen.e: Naisenshi was in charge of dyeing for string, fabric and woven fabric to be dedicated to Emperor and Empress.

sen.j: 大同 (日本)3年1月20日（808年）に行われた官司の統廃合により、中務省所属の縫殿寮に統合される（『日本後紀』の当該部分は一部失われているが、『官職秘抄』などに記されている）。
sen.e: With the elimination and consolidation of government officials on January 20, 808, it was incorporated into Nuidono-ryo (Bureau of the Wardrobe and Court Ladies) belonging to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) (the said part of "Nihon Koki" (Later Chronicle of Japan) was partly lost, but it was written in "Kanshoku hisho" (a text describing rules of ceremony and etiquette to be observed in the imperial court and by samurai that was written during the early Heian period in around 1200) and so on.

With the elimination and consolidation of government officials on February 23, 808, it was incorporated into Nuidonoryo (Bureau of the Wardrobe and Court Ladies) belonging to Nakatsukasasho (Ministry of Central Affairs) (the said part of "Nihon Koki" (Later Chronicle of Japan) was partly lost, but it was written in "Kanshoku hisho" (a text describing rules of ceremony and etiquette to be observed in the imperial court and by samurai that was written during the early Heian period in around 1200) and so on.
sen.cmt: 旧暦→新暦に修正、Nuidonoryoとしました。

sen.j: 延喜式には縫殿寮に内染司の機能を継承したとみられる「御服染作所（ごふくそめつくりどころ）」が設置され、染師の後身と見られる染手6名が配属されている。
sen.e: In "the Engishiki" (an ancient book for codes and procedures on national rites and prayers), 'Gofukusome tsukuridokoro' (the center for dyeing clothes), which succeeded to the function of naisenshi, was put in Nuidono-ryo and six Somete (dyer), who seems to have been later forms of Someshi (dyer), were staffed.
